title._content: Beatrice Collingwood, a member of the Woolloongabba troop of the Salvation Army Life Saving Guards, New Farm Park, ca. 1927

description._content: Creator: Unidentified Location: Brisbane, Queensland Description: Beatrice Collingwood was a member of the Woolloongabba troop of the Salvation Army Life Saving Guards who won a Divisional Efficiency Shield. See image 127862. (Description supplied with photograph) The Life Saving Guards were inaugurated by Mrs. General Booth on 17 November 1915 with the aim of providing enrichment for the body, mind and spirit of its members. The uniform was grey and red. Brigades were divided into patrols and were under the direction of a Guard Leader. Each girl worked to become a second class and then a first class guard. After this there was a further honour to be achieved - the General's tassle. There were also a large number of badges which could be worked for such as First Aid, Athlete, Hostess etc and these were worn on the arm of the uniform. Guard troops met weekly and often included camping in their programmes. In 1959 the Guards became Guides in the Girl Guide Association. (Information taken from: The Salvation Army International Heritage Centre, 2010, retrieved 22 February 2010, from www1.salvationarmy.org.uk/uki\www_uki_ihc.nsf/stc-vw-sublinks/303480286DE9C9CC8025704D004447D3?openDocument). View this image at the State Library of Queensland: hdl.handle.net/10462/deriv/193084 Information about State Library of Queensland’s collection: pictureqld.slq.qld.gov.au/
